captions.text:
- [Man with Microphone]
What advice would you
give to the young girls of the world?
("Remembering")
- Let your work speak for yourself.
- To not live someone else's life

and someone else's idea
of what womanhood is.
Womanhood is you.

Womanhood is everything
that's inside of you.
- Be absolutely who you are.
And stick to your instinct and your guts,
and don't try and be like other people.
- And don't take the Nike campaigns
and the Victoria's Secret campaigns

and think you need bigger
boobs or a better butt
or you need a tighter ab or whatever else.
Be happy with who you are
and love your insecurities because

when you grow up, I think that's
what's gonna make you you,

it's gonna differentiate
you from the group.
So, that's what my moms always told me.
I followed it.

- It's so easy to spread the
message of being yourself,

but actually sort of
implementing it in your life
is incredibly difficult.
I think it takes a long time to find

what makes you happy
and what your goals are.
- To not think in color.
Don't think in color.

You can feel in color because
obviously it's beautiful
and it's the best, but not think it.
And that shouldn't be the first thing
you think about when you wake up
and the first thing you think about
when you walk out your door.
Think about yourself.
- I think we have to do things
to keep a balance in our lives,

and not let any institution,
such as Hollywood,
define who we are.
You gotta know who you are
and present that.

- All women, anyone,
don't ask for permission.
What are you waiting for?
What are you asking for?
- And yes, it's gonna be a struggle,
and yes, you're gonna hear a lot of no's
before you hear a yes,

but learn to enjoy the
process and embrace it,
and have fun with it.
- Work hard.
Be so good they can't ignore you.

Keep to your morals, see
through your integrity,
and don't stop fighting

because ultimately for
any dream, for any goal,
it takes a lifetime.
And why wouldn't you wanna give it that?
It's not a race.
It's a journey, and enjoy the journey.
("Remembering")

title: Advice To Young Women From The Oscars Red Carpet

comments.author: Mixantropaz

comments.text:
I love this video and love the fact that there is such a positive force 
promoting self-acceptance and empowerment of women.

HOWEVER, I can't help but feel that as a young man, I am being forgotten 
about, cast aside, and devalued. 

I grew up in poverty in Michigan but I am told that 'poverty is sexist' and 
that women are affected by poverty. I graduated salutatorian from high 
school and I am told it is because men are given more attention in school. 
I got into an Ivy League school and I am told as a white male that (even 
though I personally know minorities who were favored based on unique 
factors). I realize that we have an overall sexist society but I also am in 
need of reaffirmations and inspiration as a man.﻿
comments.author: Jackson Blankenship

comments.text: Check out this video on YouTube:﻿
comments.author: Jason Castro

comments.text:
I think the biggest misunderstanding is the phrase, just be who you are. It 
should really be, 'Be what you want to be'. Strive to be the best you, that 
you can imagine. If that means to you going to school for your PhD, do 
that. If it means taking acting classes, do that. If it means training to 
participate in a particular sport, do it.  If it means getting plastic 
surgery to even the playing field with those who were born naturally 
beautiful, do that. Don't be satisfied with being average. Even those who 
start out average can become outstanding if they try hard enough. Don't let 
other people's limitations become your own.﻿
comments.author: Deb B

comments.author: Gymnast1214

comments.text:
I wish my mother cherish the love and the love of women hood, to learn to 
have such a great impact on her girls, including myself. I wish I could say 
I have an inspiring role model, and I know that everyone does not, but it 
would be nice to have someone "so close to you" be able to know and 
understand, to help you  through any situation. This might be asking for a 
bit much but that's honestly all I want. I want the older women to stop 
holding back (if you are) and talk, lead, and not only share your stories 
but help guide the younger women on a better path. Life is not a 
competition, this team is only as strong as you make. If we don't have that 
bond or trust we can all fall. Don't have that feeling inside thinking 
'this generation' should go through what you went through. If we do then we 
aren't changing, nothing isn't happening, we aren't making a difference, we 
aren't getting stronger, nor wiser. If you don't guide us then who can 
guide if we haven't been lead? This is what makes our generation so 
special. Young girls have gotten the courage to sit in front of a camera 
once a week to acknowledge problems we may have. This is change, this is 
guiding. So I want to thank any lady who has ever stop to give advice or 
encouragement to women in general. At the end of the day we all need each 
other and we all need a little inspiration. If you are reading this I want 
you to know that you are who you are because you are special, you have the 
choice of your individuality meaning you are your own person and no one can 
take that away from you. You are what you put yourself out to be, today 
just randomly approach someone and tell them something nice, I can already 
feel the change!

Thank you
~Allie﻿

comments.text:
I am so sick of guys complaining to girls about how they aren't treated 
fairly and girls doing the same for guys and how both sides say they are 
wronged. The number on both sides who say that the other side don't deserve 
or need help or advice themselves. This video was beautiful and sent a 
fantastic message but some of these points can be applied to men as well 
but equally to those out there who are saying men don't need advice of 
their own you are so very wrong. Believe it or not we are not all in big 
clubs; not all women need advice and not all men need advice but some do 
and all deserve to have that advice their for them to reach out to if they 
are one of those many people from both sides who do need it. Stop looking 
at it as men and women rather look at it as humanity.﻿

comments.text:
WHY, WHY DOES THERE ALWAYS HAVE TO BE - "WHAT ABOUT MEN?" "WHAT ABOUT WHITE 
PEOPLE?" "WHAT ABOUT STRAIGHT PEOPLE?"

MAYBE BECAUSE WOMEN ARE ALWAYS THE PEOPLE WHO HAVE IT STUCK IN THEIR BRAIN 
TO BE PERFECT, AND THAT ALL THEY CAN DO IS COOK AND CLEAN. 

MAYBE BECAUSE AFRICAN AMERICANS HAVE BEEN SOLD AS SLAVES IN THE PAST, AND 
NOW IN THE FUTURE A BLACK MAN WEARING A HOODIE IN THE NIGHTTIME IS FEARING 
FOR HIS LIFE. 

MAYBE BECAUSE GAYS, LESBIANS, BIS, TRANSGENDERS, A-SEXUALS, AND ETC. ARE 
BEING TOLD THAT THE WAY THEY LIVE IS "UNNATURAL" EVERY SINGLE DAY OF THEIR 
LIFE. 

MAYBE NOBODY PAYS ATTENTION TO YOU PEOPLE, WHO ARE SAYING "WHAT ABOUT ME?" 
BECAUSE YOU DON'T TAKE THE TIME TO LET OTHERS BE EMPOWERED. 
I'M SORRY NOT EVER VIDEO ON THIS CHANNEL IS ABOUT YOU, I'M SORRY THAT NOT 
EVERY SINGLE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT APPLIES TO YOU - BUT IT APPLIES TO 
SOMEONE ELSE IN THIS BIG WIDE WORLD, SO WHY ARE YOU UNABLE TO FEEL HAPPY 
FOR THAT ONE PERSON?﻿
